results.title: Killers in Eden
results.creator_credit: Klaus Toft, ABC-TV (Australia). Natural History Unit, Granada International Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
‘Killers in Eden’ is the story of perhaps the most extraordinary partnership ever forged between humans and wild animals. Locals in the Australian town of Eden claim that beginning in the mid-1800s an intimate and co-operative relationship developed between human whalers and killer whales.

The giant prey whales - minke whales, humpbacks, right whales, blue whales - were herded into Twofold Bay by the killer whales. This allowed the shore-based human whalers to close in for the kill. Working together in Eden, man and beast were able to do something neither could have managed on their own; killing the largest whales on earth. The two hunters then shared the spoils through an arrangement known as the ‘Law of the Tongue’.

Whale enthusiast Greg Mckee, who has researched this story for 15 years, joins forces with eminent zoologist Danielle Clode to investigate the intimate details of the relationship. Together, Greg and Danielle reveal not only the fascinating details of how the partnership began, but also why it tragically ended. A Co-production with Granada International.

results.title: World Series Debating: That Football is Stupid
results.creator_credit: Wendy Harmer, Andrew Denton, Ted Robinson, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Joe Murray
results.brief_description: One of the most popular events of the annual Melbourne Comedy Festival, the debate was filmed over several years by ABC TV. Campbell McComas introduces two teams of 3 people consisting of Wendy Harmer, Edmund Capon, Lex Marinos, HG Nelson, Laurie Lawrence, Andrew Denton. The topic of this debate is that football is stupid.

results.title: Landline: Stripping the Myth
results.brief_description:
‘Landline’ is the ABC’s national rural issues program.

This episode investigates the conventionally accepted history of the invention and development of the combine harvester. The widely held belief that a young Victorian, Hugo Victor McKay, was the inventor of the world’s first such machine is exposed as a myth.

First broadcast on 13th March, 2005.

results.title: Play School: Everybody Sing!
results.creator_credit: Henrietta Clark and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: ‘Everybody Sing!’ is a one hour special presentation exploring the world of music, sound and making music and contains 33 terrific songs including Miss Polly had a Dolly, Der Glumph went the Little Green Frog, Three Jelly Fish, The Toothbrush Song, The Wobbly Walk, The Bear Hunt, Goldilocks - The Musical, Baa Baa Black Sheep and lots more. Presenters include Colin Buchanan, Benita Collings, Trisha Goddard, John Hamblin, Noni Hazlehurst, Angela Moore, Philip Quast, George Spartels, Monica Trapaga.

results.title: Mother and Son: Arthur's Night Out
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Atherden, Geoffrey Portmann and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
‘Mother and Son’ was an Australian television comedy series that centred on the relationship between the elderly Maggie Beare (Ruth Cracknell) and her carer son Arthur (Garry McDonald).

In this episode, Arthur’s attempts to enjoy a night out with his estranged wife, Deirdre (Suzanne Roylance) are derailed by Maggie’s determination not to be left out.

First broadcast on 6th February, 1984.

results.title: Holeproof Computer Socks [advertisement]
results.brief_description:
A commercial for Holeproof ‘Computer Socks’ set in a patent office, where the inventor’s glee at his discovery (‘they fall up, not down’) causes Isaac Newton to rethink his theory of gravity.
Produced by Campaign Palace.
